title: People who interviewed for HackerOne security analyst position can be enumerated and their personal email address may be exposed

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
It's possible to gather basic information on potential employees (at the very least who interviewed) via old sample reports not being removed from the program
**Description:**
This report is meant to provide awareness of potentially private data being accessed by potential candidates.

When given access to the h1triage program as a potential candidate, I found that I was able to view prior candidate's answers to the interview questions/scenarios as well as non-hackerone email addresses.
### Steps To Reproduce potential private email disclosure

1. Sign in as a member of the h1triage team (mock triage interview)
2. Browse to https://hackerone.com/h1triage/groups/25396/members/edit
████

### Steps To Reproduce candidate disclosure

1. Gather all reports submitted to the interview program. For sake of time I have included a curl command to gather this information. The only thing required to duplicate is a valid cookie that has access to the h1triage program

`curl --silent --cookie '<COOKIE>' -H 'Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01' 'https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?subject=h1triage&report_id=222368&view=all&substates%5B%5D=new&substates%5B%5D=triaged&substates%5B%5D=needs-more-info&substates%5B%5D=resolved&substates%5B%5D=informative&substates%5B%5D=not-applicable&substates%5B%5D=duplicate&substates%5B%5D=spam&reported_to_team=&text_query=&program_states%5B%5D=2&program_states%5B%5D=3&program_states%5B%5D=4&program_states%5B%5D=5&sort_type=latest_activity&sort_direction=descending&limit=1000&page=1' | tr ',' '\n' | grep -E '^\"id' | cut -d ':' -f 2 > ~/Desktop/reports.txt`

This will provide a list of reports that had been created for the interview process (130 in total):

... snippet ...
352430
302753
283278
273850
218861
224701
224703
224705
224737
224738
273847
283279
283285
302752
302751
302743
302756
302750
283280
283291
283284
283283
283282
273848
... snippet ...

2. Use this list to gather all triagers (potential employees). Again, a simple while loop using curl to gather said information.

`while read -r id; do curl --silent --cookie '<COOKIE>' -H 'Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01' "https://hackerone.com/reports/$id.json" | tr ',' '\n' | grep -Eo 'username.*\"' | cut -d '"' -f 3 >> ~/Desktop/candidates.txt; done < ~/Desktop/reports.txt`

What you'll be left with is a list of all potential candidates in the past year (some are hackerone employees on interview team or the fake reporter):

███████
███
███
██████████
███████
██████████
███
████████
████████
██████████
█████████
██████
██████
██████
████████
█████
███████
██████████
████████
██████
r3naissance
███
█████
████
████████
████

This list can be used to gather information on the candidate (ie, see if they were accepted as a triager) by looking up their profile and identifying if they are a member of the HackerOne team.

3. Another while loop could be used to enumerate which candidates passed the interview process and were accepted as triagers but an exmaple request can be seen below to illustrate the point.
██████████

### Resolution
The wisest choice would be to dispose of candidate information and reports as soon as they are not needed to remove the risk of potential leakage.

## Impact

While the impact is limited to candidates that passed the first round of interviews, it's still plausible that a threat actor may pose as a candidate to gain access to this information and use it to illicit social engineering attacks.

It's possible to gather basic information on potential employees (at the very least who interviewed) via old sample reports not being removed from the program
Description:
This report is meant to provide awareness of potentially private data being accessed by potential candidates.

When given access to the h1triage program as a potential candidate, I found that I was able to view prior candidate's answers to the interview questions/scenarios as well as non-hackerone email addresses.

Steps To Reproduce potential private email disclosure

  1. Sign in as a member of the h1triage team (mock triage interview)
  2. Browse to https://hackerone.com/h1triage/groups/25396/members/edit ████

Steps To Reproduce candidate disclosure

  1. Gather all reports submitted to the interview program. For sake of time I have included a curl command to gather this information. The only thing required to duplicate is a valid cookie that has access to the h1triage program

curl --silent --cookie '<COOKIE>' -H 'Accept: application/json, text/javascript, */*; q=0.01' 'https://hackerone.com/bugs.json?subject=h1triage&report_id=222368&view=all&substates%5B%5D=new&substates%5B%5D=triaged&substates%5B%5D=needs-more-info&substates%5B%5D=resolved&substates%5B%5D=informative&substates%5B%5D=not-applicable&substates%5B%5D=duplicate&substates%5B%5D=spam&reported_to_team=&text_query=&program_states%5B%5D=2&program_states%5B%5D=3&program_states%5B%5D=4&program_states%5B%5D=5&sort_type=latest_activity&sort_direction=descending&limit=1000&page=1' | tr ',' '\n' | grep -E '^\"id' | cut -d ':' -f 2 > ~/Desktop/reports.txt

The wisest choice would be to dispose of candidate information and reports as soon as they are not needed to remove the risk of potential leakage.

While the impact is limited to candidates that passed the first round of interviews, it's still plausible that a threat actor may pose as a candidate to gain access to this information and use it to illicit social engineering attacks.

activities.message: Hi @r3naissance - thanks for your report. I'll pass this along to the Triage Team, who handle these interviews. We'll see what we can do or that we'll accept this (minor) risk for the time being. We'll get back to you next week. Happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @r3naissance - thanks for your report. I'll pass this along to the Triage Team, who handle these interviews. We'll see what we can do or that we'll accept this (minor) risk for the time being. We'll get back to you next week. Happy hacking!

activities.message:
Hi again @jobert. Absolutely, the risk is very low especially given the privileged access (just realized I miss-categorized as Medium... Apologies). I just feel potential candidates shouldn't be privy to prior interview notes/answers, the highest classification of the data is at best 'Company Internal'. Candidates should still be considered as 'Public' (limited as it may be). 

Enjoy your weekend!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi again @jobert. Absolutely, the risk is very low especially given the privileged access (just realized I miss-categorized as Medium... Apologies). I just feel potential candidates shouldn't be privy to prior interview notes/answers, the highest classification of the data is at best 'Company Internal'. Candidates should still be considered as 'Public' (limited as it may be).

Enjoy your weekend!

activities.message: Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, @r3naissance! We're going to update our internal process to make sure the data is scrubbed between interviews or we're going to set up a new program for each interviewee. We should be able to close this out somewhere next week. Thanks again and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks again for bringing this to our attention, @r3naissance! We're going to update our internal process to make sure the data is scrubbed between interviews or we're going to set up a new program for each interviewee. We should be able to close this out somewhere next week. Thanks again and happy hacking!

activities.message: Hi @r3naissance - we've updated our process and are now creating a new program each time we interview someone. We've also removed everybody from the `h1triage` program to avoid people exploiting this when this report becomes public. Thanks again for pointing this out. We took some time to consider our options here, hence the delay in resolving this. Thanks for your patience and we look forward to receive reports from you again in the future. We'll redact the information in the report and request public disclosure soon. Thanks and happy hacking!
activities.markdown_message: Hi @r3naissance - we've updated our process and are now creating a new program each time we interview someone. We've also removed everybody from the h1triage program to avoid people exploiting this when this report becomes public. Thanks again for pointing this out. We took some time to consider our options here, hence the delay in resolving this. Thanks for your patience and we look forward to receive reports from you again in the future. We'll redact the information in the report and request public disclosure soon. Thanks and happy hacking!

additional_data.old_title: Perspective employees can be enumerated as well as private email address disclosure
additional_data.new_title: People who interviewed for HackerOne security analyst position can be enumerated and their personal email address may be exposed
